reports.title: Fake Return Scams: Secure Your Crypto Investments
reports.description:
Phishing scam operating via Twitch live streams impersonating 'ThreadGuy' and pump.fun founder Alon. The stream broadcasts pre-recorded footage and uses an overlay directing viewers to a malicious website (cashback.padretrade.fun) to claim a fake 8 SOL reward. Connecting a wallet to this site triggers a malicious transaction that drains user funds. The scammer frequently creates new Twitch accounts (currently: threadguyofflclailive) to evade platform bans.

reports.description:
he website xjembet.com induced cryptocurrency transfers by falsely claiming that deposits were required for AML/KYC verification and withdrawal activation.After each payment, new undisclosed requirements were introduced, including wallet verification and VIP status deposits.The operator justified these demands by referencing non-existent FATF/AML rules. Withdrawals remain blocked unless further payments are made.This matches known withdrawal-lock scam patterns.

he website xjembet.com induced cryptocurrency transfers by falsely claiming that deposits were required for AML/KYC verification and withdrawal activation.

After each payment, new undisclosed requirements were introduced, including wallet verification and VIP status deposits.

The operator justified these demands by referencing non-existent FATF/AML rules. Withdrawals remain blocked unless further payments are made.

This matches known withdrawal-lock scam patterns.

I am a victim of physical phone theft that occurred in the United Kingdom. Following the theft, the perpetrators managed to compromise my Apple ID (iCloud) and gain unauthorized access to my device data.

Through this access, they obtained my login credentials for the Gate.io exchange and likely compromised the private keys/seed phrases stored on the device for my Solana wallet.

On December 5, 2025, the thieves executed multiple unauthorized transactions:

Gate.io Breach (Ethereum Chain): They withdrew USDT (ERC20) from my exchange account to an external attacker address.

Solana Wallet Drain: They transferred SOL from my personal wallet to two different attacker addresses.

The total loss is approximately $2,880 USD. This case has been reported to the UK Police (Action Fraud).--- INCIDENT 1: Ethereum (USDT via Gate.io) ---

--- INCIDENT 2: Solana (Wallet Drain) ---

The domain bearmarketcoin.vip is impersonating the legitimate crypto project Bear Market Coin by using an identical/confusingly similar name and narrative to mislead users.
The website promotes a token that has already been launched, and on-chain activity shows strong indicators of fraudulent behavior, including extreme supply concentration, early large sell-offs, and visible investor losses shortly after launch.
This domain is not affiliated with the official project in any way. It is creating confusion among users, causing reputational damage to the brand, and exposing the public to potential financial harm.

On November 22, 2025, cryptocurrency was stolen from two wallets that I had on my computer in soft wallets. I did not authorize these transactions and have not looked at these wallets in several months. The first unauthorized transaction was the attacker unstaked my Solana on November 20th. I only noticed this all today, December 6, 2025.

The seed phrases for my Solana and Ethereum / Polygon wallets were stored in my NordPass password manager on my MacBook Air, and a NordPass recovery code was stored in a PDF in my Documents folder, which had been uploaded to iCloud Drive.

I have not found evidence of obvious remote logins or malware, but based on the timing and the fact that my seed phrases and recovery code were stored on this device, I suspect my Mac, my NordPass vault, or the NordPass recovery code PDF may have been compromised.

The hacker seemingly used my seed phrases stored in Nordpass to access my wallets, sent the funds to themselves through various transactions.

I ran Malwarebytes scan and found no known malware on my computer.Transactions:Solana unstaking transactions:

https://solscan.io/tx/jTYHSMQjCRHQ2RAPCDJhawi3bRxv3hreuyuMJrymXpBn3HQgyieboGJbA9Q2xGXHtPJKDp7Y8SEuFUz3BbinJQW

5. Em menos de 5 minutos após a importação, o criminoso executou múltiplas transações transferindo todos os ativos para sua própria carteira.

6. O criminoso primeiro fechou as posições alavancadas da vítima na plataforma Jupiter Perps para liberar o colateral, e então transferiu todos os fundos.

reports.title: Fake Crypto Projects: Spot and Report Scams
reports.description:
First they will reach out to you via Twitter and will offer a signal and project pre-sales with whales. Then will ask you to reach out on @xbauuch on telegram to be added on their private tg and they will offer a pre-sale for public launch. They will ask you to pay @mickey7055 for private ID and minimum Solana for pre-sale, then they will kept increasing the minimum for you to top-up. Once you agreed to not send again for a minimum, they will ask for you to set-up a bot @Basedbot0_bot which should have a tokens to continue the air drop. It requires to sign-up for this bot to receive the token allocation which you have already paid, however, you can't sign up to this bot without inputting your wallet seed phrase.

I'm a crypto novice. I bought some Ace Data Cloud coin ($ACE) and recently they announced a migration of the coin so I joined their discord channel to find out if there was anything special I needed to do to secure my coin for the migration since I'm not really knowledgeable in crypto processes and I didn't want to lose it.Someone in the discord that goes by Naji408 said "You will when the window opens". A 2-3 seconds later a discord support ticket window opens and I joined it. I assumed this was the window Naji408 meant. (I've since talked with Naji408 after being robbed and he's explained that is not what he meant. He meant the window in time when the migration takes place in the near future.)Someone else in the discord, Kuroshio7908, added me as a friend and I accepted the friend request. In the ACE server he was in the "waiting room" tab which is locked and requires a code to enter, I assumed he was someone official in the server. After joining the support ticket Kuroshio7908 was in both the ACE and support ticket servers with me.The discord support ticket I joined appears to be a separate and different server than the ACE coin discord server. I don't use discord often so I'm not certain. It may be a fake support ticket or something that lured me away from the ACE discord into a scammer's discord disguised as a support ticket.There I spoke with an "Admin" who said I had to whitelist my coin and instructed me to go to a website (serterix.com - do not use this, you will get robbed) and connect my wallet. When you try to connect your wallet, the website pretends to have trouble connecting and prompts you to connect manually. It gives you 3 options, Json, private key, or your seed phrase/secret recovery phrase.Red flags and alarm bells go off. It looked suspicious so I googled it real quick and I couldn't find anything to really authenticate it, but I couldn't find anything saying it was a scam either. I voiced my concern to the Admin in the support ticket, they said it was legit. I believed them and chose to use my private key. (I knew the seed phrase should never be shared but I wasn't aware so much of the private key, I thought it was needed to verify my coin, I was wrong.) This time it gave me a checkmark, but nothing happened. There was no next step to whitelist my ACE coin. Refresh the page, same connect sign, and again, nothing.I let the Admin know it's not doing anything, he asks which option I chose, I told him private key, he said try the seed phrase. Now the alarm bells are getting louder. I google the website I just gave my private key to. I find one random review on a different site (www.trustpilot.com). It says someone used it to scam them. I foolishly let the Admin know that I think it's a scam. (What I should have done is immediately transfer my coin to a different wallet)After I tell him I think it's a scam he gives me a link to some fake white papers to show that it's not a scam. It's 2 pages, obviously fake, but does it's job distracting me long enough for them to empty my wallet. Now I'm pissed.I go back to the ACE discord, it's been about a half hour since I joined the support ticket, no activity since Naji408 said "you will when the window opens", no elaboration or explanation what "the window" means. I start sounding the alarm, saying I've been robbed. I post a screenshot of the website review in the discord. I then get banned with no warning. Next I'm on the coin's twitter page warning people and looking for Naji408 and Kuroshio7908.Eventually I find Naji408, not long after I find him we talk, he denies any involvement. He explains "the window" meant a time window in the future during the migration process. He admits he's the one who banned me, he explains he did it because I posted a screen shot and he thought it was soliciting or something and he was just doing what he was typically told to do in that scenario. He says he has no idea who Kuroshio7908 is. He seems honest, however I can't confirm or deny whether he sent the support ticket window or not.Kuroshio7908 vanished from both servers. Naji408 was never in the support ticket server and is still in the ACE server being helpful to anyone with questions and he's continued to work with me to solve this after I called him a thief. I think Naji's innocent, but I don't know for certain.

On Nov 27, 2025, I attempted to create a Solana meme token through the website https://memsolcoins.org. During the process, I was instructed to send 2.9 SOL to a wallet address provided by the website: 25NxjFrBuCAZyiWVPSCN52GjXYdeJ3R4nVTSuc7ZxXZc. I later realized the website may be fraudulent, and the SOL was sent to a wallet I do not control. The transaction hash is 4yuxVWcYd2YkKmjczFtiD1Xx7MScXEwm5MBGwNSYvLtSDECWd3ujiT53S5JTTaU4RKRrcqtRsAwoDNLU9bxWZFwW.The total value lost was 2.9 SOL (~$410.65) at the time of the transaction. The scam appears to be a rug pull or fraudulent token creation platform. I am reporting this to alert the community, provide all relevant details for investigation, and seek guidance on whether the destination wallet can be monitored or flagged.Evidence includes screenshots of the transaction on Solscan and the website interface showing the wallet address instructions.

I made total of 5,6 $SOL from October until recently. 2 transacions from MEXC 0.5 SOL and 1 SOL, and 2 transactions from Phantom wallet, once 2 SOL and second 2.1 SOL. I have received all $CR7 in Phantom wallet, on MEXC still did not (they said it will be after listing if ever listed on MEXC). After last transaction, things get weird in community channel. No news, no engagements. Silence for few days. And after one normal sentence on telegram group, I was kicked out, support deleted all history that I made with them in chat. Then I went again investigating everything and found out that every single SOL entering main wallet was pulled out almost immediately to other newly created accounts which can bee seen on solscan I have provided. Plus, there were several launch postpones already. Counter for sold CR7 on their site went from 99% to 76%, than on 92% recently. There wasn't any big investments lately so this also doesn't makes any sense.

reports.title: Fake Crypto Projects: Spot and Report Scams
reports.description:
On or around 7th November: I applied for a blockchain job at Dredsoftlabs.com via jobright.ai.Method of Contact: The communication occurred via telegram.The "Recruiter": On 10th November, the person Leo Broughton (Fake name) reached out to me about a company they called Dredsoftlabs.com.The Scam: We proceeded with scheduling with what I believed was a legitimate interview process. As a required step, on 12th November, I was instructed to download and install a specific software application.Stated Purpose of Software: They claimed this software was for a coding test for the interview.The Malware: On 12th November, I downloaded the software from a link they provided: https://bitbucket.org/topstars/tech-test/src/main/. I executed the npm start command to run the software.The Theft: On 13th November they scheduled a video call (their face was not visible) where I had to type my password to open metamask and immediately after the videocall, unauthorized transactions were made from my Metamask wallet. My Conclusion: I now believe this software was a malicious Trojan or "infostealer" designed to find and export my Metamask wallet's private keys or seed phrase stored in my computer's browser data, giving the attackers full control of my wallet.I believe that it could be related to lazarus terrorist group as I see that attack similar to https://www.wjhl.com/business/press-releases/ein-presswire/818604454/new-north-korean-malware-ottercookie-uses-fake-job-offers-to-steal-credentials/

On or around 7th November: I applied for a blockchain job at Dredsoftlabs.com via jobright.ai.

Method of Contact: The communication occurred via telegram.

The "Recruiter": On 10th November, the person Leo Broughton (Fake name) reached out to me about a company they called Dredsoftlabs.com.

The Scam: We proceeded with scheduling with what I believed was a legitimate interview process. As a required step, on 12th November, I was instructed to download and install a specific software application.

Stated Purpose of Software: They claimed this software was for a coding test for the interview.

The Malware: On 12th November, I downloaded the software from a link they provided: https://bitbucket.org/topstars/tech-test/src/main/. I executed the npm start command to run the software.

The Theft: On 13th November they scheduled a video call (their face was not visible) where I had to type my password to open metamask and immediately after the videocall, unauthorized transactions were made from my Metamask wallet.

My Conclusion: I now believe this software was a malicious Trojan or "infostealer" designed to find and export my Metamask wallet's private keys or seed phrase stored in my computer's browser data, giving the attackers full control of my wallet.

I believe that it could be related to lazarus terrorist group as I see that attack similar to https://www.wjhl.com/business/press-releases/ein-presswire/818604454/new-north-korean-malware-ottercookie-uses-fake-job-offers-to-steal-credentials/

Amount lost

86000.00 USD

In October 2025 I applied for what appeared to be a remote job opportunity on a site that presented itself as a legitimate recruiting page. The scammers operated at least two fraudulent domains related to this scheme:1. https://www.netaporterjob.com/ — hosted on Wix.com (IP 34.149.87.45).2. https://www.naporter.shop/#/ — hosted via Cloudflare, Inc. (IP 172.67.138.48, United States).After registering on the fraudulent site(s) I was contacted by individuals using WhatsApp and Telegram. They persuaded me to transfer funds in cryptocurrency as part of the “onboarding/payment” / deposit process described by the scammers.Financial transfers and losses (breakdown):BityBank — USD 14,751.79Crypto — USD 24.401,13Mercado Bitcoin — USD 5,403.33Funds initially deposited into the wallets above were later routed to accounts on exchanges (which I have identified during my own investigation). The primary receiving exchanges/accounts where funds ended up are: BityBank, Crypto, and Mercado Bitcoin (values listed above). I have found associated accounts on LBank that received funds originating from Destination address: 1) Trou4EavgzEMoBp3V93LNaaiKY3Y3Rg5Cx2) TeqiXhjxBXenG3wvA2YiyDwJTuw6jeioerOther relevant details / indicators:My initial support request to LBank was registered under ticket number W4VFPN, but since I am not a direct customer of LBank, I was informed that no assistance could be provided. However. I am now seeking your collaboration with law enforcement for the formal investigation that has been opened in Brazil (Police Report No. PP8152-1/2025).The fraudulent webpages are impersonating a legitimate recruiting/job listing appearance and were hosted on platforms/services with infrastructure in the United States.Scammers used messaging apps (WhatsApp and Telegram) to guide me through conversion of my funds into crypto and to provide transaction instructions.I possess screenshots of the web pages, chat histories, wallet addresses, and transaction confirmations. I also have the on-chain links above confirming movement of tokens from the deposit addresses to the destination wallets/exchanges.

In October 2025 I applied for what appeared to be a remote job opportunity on a site that presented itself as a legitimate recruiting page. The scammers operated at least two fraudulent domains related to this scheme:

1. https://www.netaporterjob.com/ — hosted on Wix.com (IP 34.149.87.45).

2. https://www.naporter.shop/#/ — hosted via Cloudflare, Inc. (IP 172.67.138.48, United States).

After registering on the fraudulent site(s) I was contacted by individuals using WhatsApp and Telegram. They persuaded me to transfer funds in cryptocurrency as part of the “onboarding/payment” / deposit process described by the scammers.Financial transfers and losses (breakdown):

BityBank — USD 14,751.79

Crypto — USD 24.401,13

Mercado Bitcoin — USD 5,403.33

Funds initially deposited into the wallets above were later routed to accounts on exchanges (which I have identified during my own investigation). The primary receiving exchanges/accounts where funds ended up are: BityBank, Crypto, and Mercado Bitcoin (values listed above). I have found associated accounts on LBank that received funds originating from Destination address:

1) Trou4EavgzEMoBp3V93LNaaiKY3Y3Rg5Cx

2) TeqiXhjxBXenG3wvA2YiyDwJTuw6jeioer

Other relevant details / indicators:My initial support request to LBank was registered under ticket number W4VFPN, but since I am not a direct customer of LBank, I was informed that no assistance could be provided. However.

I am now seeking your collaboration with law enforcement for the formal investigation that has been opened in Brazil (Police Report No. PP8152-1/2025).

The fraudulent webpages are impersonating a legitimate recruiting/job listing appearance and were hosted on platforms/services with infrastructure in the United States.

Scammers used messaging apps (WhatsApp and Telegram) to guide me through conversion of my funds into crypto and to provide transaction instructions.

I possess screenshots of the web pages, chat histories, wallet addresses, and transaction confirmations. I also have the on-chain links above confirming movement of tokens from the deposit addresses to the destination wallets/exchanges.

Amount lost

44556.25 USD

reports.title: Fake Return Scams: Secure Your Crypto Investments
reports.description:
This woman reached out pretending to want to purchase a home. I was given fake bank statement and drivers license. after a few weeks talk began about investing in crypto when I asked her how she had so much cash. She said she works with people over the world who use the platform Coinxax and they provide me with the amount to trade and when to execute. I started with $800 and with the promising returns i invested more until I was up to 38k plus in funds. My account grew to over $127,000 in total funds with "fake Profits". When I wanted to remove funds I was given one withdrawal of 5k and after that everything was blocked. I was then told by Keith that I could either pay an up front 25k to have my funds released that day or wait 6 months. I asked her for the funds and of course she denied me. I then went to the local police dept who would not let me file a report saying I had to wait 6 months but they did check the driver's license which they told me was fake.  I am devestated. I filed with IC3

I was recently scammed through a fake website pretending to be a Solana token creation platform called solmemecoins.org. The site looked legitimate and asked me to connect my Phantom wallet and pay to create a token. I paid the requested amount in SOL, and the transaction shows as “Success” on Solscan.After I paid, the site falsely claimed that “no payments were found” and then a supposed “support agent” told me to send another payment equal to the first one for verification. That’s when I realized it was a scam.

I had just received the Solana Seeker phone. Knowing the 1st Solana was pre-installed with NFTs, Bonk tokens etc I stupidly thought the same would be on the new Seeker phone. So when I start the phone up a JUP token airdrop popped up and pressed it. That gave access to my 'staking' account. So much SOL, SUI, stash was gone. I think they got to all my accounts when I tried to install my Phantom wallet using my Seed phrase. After that all my wallets were emptied. So I don't know if the hackers got into one wallet they got access to all the wallets before I put my Seed phrase in? Or they copied the seed phrase when I was trying to install it? Can anyone enlighten me?

I met Martin S. on LinkedIn in July 2025. Over the course of several months, he persuaded me to transfer funds totaling $405,000.00 to a Coinbase account for the benefit of my special needs daughter.  He instructed the purchase of Solana crypto in three separate transactions, and I sent each purchase to what I believed to be my trading account. The crypto was in fact, sent to his account.  I initiated trading transactions on what I believe was my account on 9/27/25 and 10/10/25.

After reading about this, typical pig-butchering scam.  I answered a Facebook ad, made contact with "Emily" who connected me with the Winchester Community.  Followed that group via WhatsApp.  There they initially provided stock market training and offered profitable trades.  These all worked out great.  Communication was either in the training group through WhatsApp or through Emily via Telegram.  These trades were made through our own brokerage accounts.  (I'm assuming to gain our trust that they knew what they were doing.)The group's founder, "Walter Cross" and his technologists were building an AI capable of making stock picks based on taking in all kinds of market news and statistics.  This is the Darvis Intelligent Analysis System.Eventually, they wanted some beta testers to do crypto futures trading.  We signed up for an account on an exchange called RapidBitEx, which was a phone app (came to find out later there was also apparently a web version).  The app is called Rapidbt and apparently is no longer available in the app store.  I'll call this the 'platform'.The test accounts were loaded with $100K and that was used for the simulated crypto futures trades.After the testing, they declared the system stable enough that we could open our own accounts on that exchange.  I did so and funded the account with $2500 worth of ETH from Coinbase (minus fees etc).  Trades went well and I added more to the account - I added two instances of $10K.  Then I added $467K from Coinbase.  I also made a wire transfer of $500K that was deposited to my account on the platform.  I was able to trade that account up to $2.3M at which time I supposedly executed a trade wrong and the account was liquidated.  Lost that entire amount.I regrouped and was able to wire in another $250K to start over.  After a few days, it was offered that I could borrow from a P2P provider associated with the platform.  I 'borrowed' $250K.  From that $500K, I grew the account to $5.7M.Then the P2P loan service called my loan due and 'froze' my account until it was repaid.  I made an agreement with them that if I paid half (which included interest) they would request to have my account unfrozen whereby I would pay them the balance out of funds in my account.  This was $136500.  My account was opened but then it seemed the platform had detected some possible fraud with my account and had to do a security investigation during which time I wasn't able to move any money.  This meant I couldn't pay off my balance within the given time frame and P2P loan again froze my account.At this point, they told me if I didn't pay the balance they would take over my account.  It was somewhere between paying them the 1/2 and the refreezing of my account I decided it was a scam and basically quit contact.  I can't access my account anymore, though I am still a member of the active WhatsApp group.

After reading about this, typical pig-butchering scam.  I answered a Facebook ad, made contact with "Emily" who connected me with the Winchester Community.  Followed that group via WhatsApp.  There they initially provided stock market training and offered profitable trades.  These all worked out great.  Communication was either in the training group through WhatsApp or through Emily via Telegram.  These trades were made through our own brokerage accounts.  (I'm assuming to gain our trust that they knew what they were doing.)

The group's founder, "Walter Cross" and his technologists were building an AI capable of making stock picks based on taking in all kinds of market news and statistics.  This is the Darvis Intelligent Analysis System.

Eventually, they wanted some beta testers to do crypto futures trading.  We signed up for an account on an exchange called RapidBitEx, which was a phone app (came to find out later there was also apparently a web version).  The app is called Rapidbt and apparently is no longer available in the app store.  I'll call this the 'platform'.

The test accounts were loaded with $100K and that was used for the simulated crypto futures trades.

After the testing, they declared the system stable enough that we could open our own accounts on that exchange.  I did so and funded the account with $2500 worth of ETH from Coinbase (minus fees etc).  Trades went well and I added more to the account - I added two instances of $10K.  Then I added $467K from Coinbase.  I also made a wire transfer of $500K that was deposited to my account on the platform.  I was able to trade that account up to $2.3M at which time I supposedly executed a trade wrong and the account was liquidated.  Lost that entire amount.

I regrouped and was able to wire in another $250K to start over.  After a few days, it was offered that I could borrow from a P2P provider associated with the platform.  I 'borrowed' $250K.  From that $500K, I grew the account to $5.7M.

Then the P2P loan service called my loan due and 'froze' my account until it was repaid.  I made an agreement with them that if I paid half (which included interest) they would request to have my account unfrozen whereby I would pay them the balance out of funds in my account.  This was $136500.  My account was opened but then it seemed the platform had detected some possible fraud with my account and had to do a security investigation during which time I wasn't able to move any money.  This meant I couldn't pay off my balance within the given time frame and P2P loan again froze my account.

At this point, they told me if I didn't pay the balance they would take over my account.  It was somewhere between paying them the 1/2 and the refreezing of my account I decided it was a scam and basically quit contact.

I can't access my account anymore, though I am still a member of the active WhatsApp group.

My mother who is a former accountant helps to take care of the crypto accounts for the family. My personal ledger accounts were connected to her Ledger app on her laptop, as were the accounts for my other siblings.On Monday 3rd November I received a phone call from my mother saying that she had be contacted by a detective from Holborn Police Station. They claimed that they had caught a scammer that had collected her personal details including a copy of her drivers licence and her SEED phrase for her crypto accounts along with several other potential victims. They also reassured her that she didn't have to do anything more but wait for them to come back with more information while the investigation was ongoing.  She called me to make me aware of the situation but that I should be ok and to wait until further information. I was a little sceptical but saw that my accounts were still in tact so assumed it was nothing to do with me.Later I received another call from her asking if I had moved my crypto. I said no, and then she informed me that my accounts on her app were empty. I checked my accounts from my end and saw that everything had be emptied out completely within a few minutes.I then discovered that that she had also received a phone call from someone claiming to be from some kind of crypto security department where they help to secure crypto accounts on various platforms. They had encouraged her to secure her ledger accounts and guided her through the process. They got her to open her app on her laptop and got her to log in to a fake Ledger webpage called "ledgerhelp.com". On this page, they got her to create a new SEED phrase. somehow they were able to access the accounts on her Ledger app (including mine) through this process. She never used any of the Ledger USB-keys, although they apparently tried to get her to find my brothers ledger key, which she couldn't locate. They also did the same with her kraken account and coinable account. My older brother who also had a Ledger account linked to her app lost all his funds like myself. My mother had kraken crypto staked so it wasn't easily accessible. She also lost a chance of crypto funds from her coinbase account.Unfortunately, my mother wasn't acting in good faith to try an protect us all but was unfortunately greatly manipulated and tricked into giving the scammers the access they needed to steal our crypto. My mother has been very unstable and unclear ever since the event and specific details about the scamming process have been difficult to get a clear picture of.

They also did the same with her kraken account and coinable account. My older brother who also had a Ledger account linked to her app lost all his funds like myself. My mother had kraken crypto staked so it wasn't easily accessible. She also lost a chance of crypto funds from her coinbase account.Unfortunately, my mother wasn't acting in good faith to try an protect us all but was unfortunately greatly manipulated and tricked into giving the scammers the access they needed to steal our crypto. My mother has been very unstable and unclear ever since the event and specific details about the scamming process have been difficult to get a clear picture of.

My mother who is a former accountant helps to take care of the crypto accounts for the family. My personal ledger accounts were connected to her Ledger app on her laptop, as were the accounts for my other siblings.

On Monday 3rd November I received a phone call from my mother saying that she had be contacted by a detective from Holborn Police Station. They claimed that they had caught a scammer that had collected her personal details including a copy of her drivers licence and her SEED phrase for her crypto accounts along with several other potential victims. They also reassured her that she didn't have to do anything more but wait for them to come back with more information while the investigation was ongoing.  She called me to make me aware of the situation but that I should be ok and to wait until further information. I was a little sceptical but saw that my accounts were still in tact so assumed it was nothing to do with me.

Later I received another call from her asking if I had moved my crypto. I said no, and then she informed me that my accounts on her app were empty. I checked my accounts from my end and saw that everything had be emptied out completely within a few minutes.

I then discovered that that she had also received a phone call from someone claiming to be from some kind of crypto security department where they help to secure crypto accounts on various platforms. They had encouraged her to secure her ledger accounts and guided her through the process. They got her to open her app on her laptop and got her to log in to a fake Ledger webpage called "ledgerhelp.com". On this page, they got her to create a new SEED phrase. somehow they were able to access the accounts on her Ledger app (including mine) through this process. She never used any of the Ledger USB-keys, although they apparently tried to get her to find my brothers ledger key, which she couldn't locate. They also did the same with her kraken account and coinable account. My older brother who also had a Ledger account linked to her app lost all his funds like myself. My mother had kraken crypto staked so it wasn't easily accessible. She also lost a chance of crypto funds from her coinbase account.

Unfortunately, my mother wasn't acting in good faith to try an protect us all but was unfortunately greatly manipulated and tricked into giving the scammers the access they needed to steal our crypto. My mother has been very unstable and unclear ever since the event and specific details about the scamming process have been difficult to get a clear picture of.

Solana wallet B was hacked by this same hacker about a month ago, but I had a token there that I wanted to transfer to Solana wallet A. After sending that small amount to B, I swapped the token for SOL and transferred it to A. I was just about to transfer SOL from A to a CEX when I noticed that the balance reduced to 0. I checked the transaction history and saw that it was transferred out; a transaction which I did not make. Normally I don't open my wallet, so I just kept my crypto hoping one day it would go up! But today I just happen to open my phantom wallet on November 4, 2025, and I see the balance is zero, I quickly see the transactions. I've kept some Solana and converted other remaining in USDT. There were two transections first was of converting my USDT to Solana and other was all my Solana was transfer to another wallet. The transaction was made on October 30, 2025. I haven't touched my wallet in like 6 months and the recovery phase is also in secure place. I don't know how they gain access to my wallet and did this robbery. I did have my wallet extension on my web browser so maybe they get to my browser and to my saved password/information. even though it's not a big amount for some but it was my savings Afterall. I'm no expert in tech world and I have faced this scam First time, so I'm somewhat freaked out. I hope this scammer/hacker caught fast ASAP. No one should face what I'm Going through. Stay safe and be aware these guys need tiny window to get to your device and wipe you off. Peace.
